DataElement.preferredName: Transgene Gene Modification Gene Or Gene Product Name
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the gene or gene product that was used in transgene gene modification.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A transgene is an engineered gene consisting at least of a regulatory element and a coding sequence; regulatory element and coding sequence can come from different species. (caBIO)_Any gene manipulation method used to generate a product with an altered sequence, structure, or conformation.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A transgene is an engineered gene consisting at least of a regulatory element and a coding sequence; regulatory element and coding sequence can come from different species. (caBIO)

Concepts.definition: An engineered gene consisting at least of a regulatory element and a coding sequence; regulatory element and coding sequence can come from different species.

Property.preferredDefinition: Any gene manipulation method used to generate a product with an altered sequence, structure, or conformation.

Concepts.definition: Any gene manipulation method used to generate a product with an altered sequence, structure, or conformation.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function._An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise._A protein, RNA or a complex that contains proteins and/or RNA._The words or language units by which a thing is known.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Coagulation factor IX (461 aa, ~52 kDa) is encoded by the human F9 gene. This protein plays a role in the intrinsic pathway of blood coagulation through the mediation of proteolysis that converts factor X into an active protease.

Concepts.definition: Coagulation factor IX (461 aa, ~52 kDa) is encoded by the human F9 gene. This protein plays a role in the intrinsic pathway of blood coagulation through the mediation of proteolysis that converts factor X into an active protease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This gene is involved in G protein-coupled signal transduction and chemotaxis.

Concepts.definition: This gene is involved in G protein-coupled signal transduction and chemotaxis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Coagulation factor VIII (2351 aa, ~267 kDa) is encoded by the human F8 gene. This protein plays a role in the modulation of coagulation factor IX activity and blood coagulation.

Concepts.definition: Coagulation factor VIII (2351 aa, ~267 kDa) is encoded by the human F8 gene. This protein plays a role in the modulation of coagulation factor IX activity and blood coagulation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The T-cell antigen receptors consist of a heterodimer of integral membrane glycoproteins. Two distinct receptors exist, alpha/beta and gamma/delta. Alpha/beta receptors are found on helper and cytotoxic T-cells and are specific for antigenic peptides presented in association with MHC gene products. Gamma/delta receptors, found in association with CD3, directly recognize proteins and non-proteinacious phospho-ligands. Alpha/beta and gamma/delta are non-covalently associated with CD3-gamma, -delta, -epsilon, and -zeta proteins, forming the TCR-CD3 complex, which activate MAPKs and JNK1 through the CD3 antigens, the adaptor protein LAT, and tyrosine kinases LCK and ZAP70. The genes for T-cell receptor subunits are encoded by distinct gene elements that are assembled by somatic rearrangement during T-cell development. Translocations and inversions of these loci are observed in human T-cell leukemias and lymphomas.

Concepts.definition: The T-cell antigen receptors consist of a heterodimer of integral membrane glycoproteins. Two distinct receptors exist, alpha/beta and gamma/delta. Alpha/beta receptors are found on helper and cytotoxic T-cells and are specific for antigenic peptides presented in association with MHC gene products. Gamma/delta receptors, found in association with CD3, directly recognize proteins and non-proteinacious phospho-ligands. Alpha/beta and gamma/delta are non-covalently associated with CD3-gamma, -delta, -epsilon, and -zeta proteins, forming the TCR-CD3 complex, which activate MAPKs and JNK1 through the CD3 antigens, the adaptor protein LAT, and tyrosine kinases LCK and ZAP70. The genes for T-cell receptor subunits are encoded by distinct gene elements that are assembled by somatic rearrangement during T-cell development. Translocations and inversions of these loci are observed in human T-cell leukemias and lymphomas.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A family of genes whose members encode globin family proteins, which are globular heme-containing proteins and include androglobin, cryoglobin, hemoglobin subunits, myoglobin and neuroglobin.

Concepts.definition: A family of genes whose members encode globin family proteins, which are globular heme-containing proteins and include androglobin, cryoglobin, hemoglobin subunits, myoglobin and neuroglobin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This gene plays a role in the import of fatty acids and acyl-coenzyme A (acylCoA)-conjugated fatty acids into the peroxisome.

Concepts.definition: This gene plays a role in the import of fatty acids and acyl-coenzyme A (acylCoA)-conjugated fatty acids into the peroxisome.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A family of proteins that are essential for the presentation of peptide antigens on cell surfaces that modulate the host defensive activities of T-cells. This protein family includes major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I and class II proteins.

Concepts.definition: A family of proteins that are essential for the presentation of peptide antigens on cell surfaces that modulate the host defensive activities of T-cells. This protein family includes major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I and class II proteins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This gene is involved in T cell activation and proliferation.

Concepts.definition: This gene is involved in T cell activation and proliferation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This gene plays a role in the transport of oxygen to tissues of the body in the fetus and neonate.: Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.: This gene plays a role in the transport of oxygen to tissues of the body in the fetus and the neonate.

Concepts.definition: This gene plays a role in the transport of oxygen to tissues of the body in the fetus and neonate.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
This gene plays a role in the transport of oxygen to tissues of the body in the fetus and the neonate.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: This gene is involved in both the modulation of cell shape and lymphopoiesis.

Concepts.definition: This gene is involved in both the modulation of cell shape and lymphopoiesis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: A transgene is an engineered gene consisting at least of a regulatory element and a coding sequence; regulatory element and coding sequence can come from different species. (caBIO)

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
An engineered gene consisting at least of a regulatory element and a coding sequence; regulatory element and coding sequence can come from different species.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Short Hairpin RNA Or Small Interfering RNA To BCL11A Gene

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Short Hairpin RNA Or Small Interfering RNA To BCL11A Gene
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An artificial RNA molecule with a tight hairpin turn that can be used to silence target gene expression via RNA interference (RNAi).: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: A 20 to 25-nucleotide double-stranded RNA which is involved in a sequence-specific messenger RNA degradation process known as RNA interference.: Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.: This gene is involved in both the modulation of cell shape and lymphopoiesis.

Concepts.definition: An artificial RNA molecule with a tight hairpin turn that can be used to silence target gene expression via RNA interference (RNAi).

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
A 20 to 25-nucleotide double-stranded RNA which is involved in a sequence-specific messenger RNA degradation process known as RNA interference.
Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.
This gene is involved in both the modulation of cell shape and lymphopoiesis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Human HBB wt allele is located in the vicinity of 11p15.5 and is approximately 4 kb in length. This allele, which encodes hemoglobin subunit beta protein, plays a role in the transport of oxygen to tissues of the body. Mutations in this gene are associated with beta-thalassemia.

Concepts.definition: Human HBB wt allele is located in the vicinity of 11p15.5 and is approximately 4 kb in length. This allele, which encodes hemoglobin subunit beta protein, plays a role in the transport of oxygen to tissues of the body. Mutations in this gene are associated with beta-thalassemia.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position (locus) on a particular chromosome, is capable of reproducing itself exactly at each cell division, and directs the formation of a protein or other product. The gene as a functional unit consists of a discrete segment of a giant DNA molecule containing the purine (adenine and guanine) and pyrimidine (cytosine and thymine) bases in the ordered and correct sequence that encodes a specific functional product (i.e., a protein or RNA molecule).

Concepts.definition: A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function.
